citation.article-title: Desulfotomaculum hydrothermale sp. nov., a thermophilic sulfate-reducing bacterium isolated from a terrestrial Tunisian hot spring.
citation.source: International Journal of Systematic and Evolutionary Microbiology

p.s: Description of Desulfotomaculum hydrothermale sp. nov.
Desulfotomaculum hydrothermale (hy.dro.ther.ma′le. Gr. n. hydro water; Gr. n. thermos heat; N.L. neut. adj. hydrothermale from a hydrothermal area).
Cells are slightly curved rods, about 0.5 μm wide and 2–5 μm long, and stain Gram-negative.
Oval, subterminal to terminal spores are produced that deform the cells.
Cells are motile by means of peritrichous flagella.
The pH range for growth is 5.8–8.2 (optimum pH 7.1).
Growth does not occur at NaCl concentrations above 1.5 % (w/v).
Sulfate, thiosulfate and sulfite are used as electron acceptors, but elemental sulfur, fumarate, nitrate or nitrite are not used.
As(V) is reduced to As(III) and Fe(III) is reduced to Fe(II).
Electron donors utilized in the presence of sulfate as the electron acceptor include lactate, pyruvate, formate, ethanol, butanol, glycerol, propanol and H2.
Pyruvate is fermented to acetate, H2 and CO2.
The DNA G+C content of the type strain is 46.8 mol% (by HPLC).
The type strain, Lam5T (=DSM 18033T =JCM 13992T), was isolated from a terrestrial hot spring in Tunisia.
